nominalpy.maths package

Submodules

nominalpy.maths.astro module

This module contains public methods that can calculate various astrophysical parameters. These include fetching planetary gravity or return the position and velocity from an orbit.

nominalpy.maths.astro.argument_of_latitude(argument_of_periapsis: float, anomaly: float, angle_max=6.283185307179586) → float

Calculate the argument of latitude from the argument of periapsis and the true/mean anomaly.

If the input anomaly is the true anomaly, then the corresponding argument of latitude will be the true argument of

latitude. Conversely, if the input anomaly is the mean anomaly, then the corresponding argument of latitude will be the mean argument of latitude.

Parameters:

  • argument_of_periapsis (float) – [rad] Argument of periapsis

  • anomaly (float) – [rad] True anomaly

  • angle_max (float) – [rad] Maximum angle to normalize the argument of latitude to. If the argument of periapsis and anomaly are expressed in radians, then angle_max should be 2*np.pi. If the argument of periapsis and anomaly are expressed in degrees, then angle_max should be 360.

Returns:

[rad] Argument of latitude

Return type:

float

nominalpy.maths.astro.calculate_circular_orbit_velocity(semi_major_axis: float, gm=398600441400000.0) → float

Calculates the magnitude of the orbital velocity for a spacecraft in a circular orbit.

Parameters:

  • semi_major_axis (float) – The semi-major axis of the spacecraft’s orbit. It must be a non-negative value - m

  • gm (float) – The gravitational parameter, defaulting to Earth’s gravitational parameter if not provided - m^3/s^2.

Returns:

The magnitude of the spacecraft’s orbital velocity resulting in a circular orbit - m/s.

Return type:

float

nominalpy.maths.astro.calculate_orbital_velocity(r_bn_n_mag: float, semi_major_axis: float, gm: float = 398600441400000.0) → float

Calculate the magnitude of the orbital velocity for a spacecraft in any orbit type.

This function uses the vis-viva equation to compute the orbital speed of a spacecraft at a given distance from the

Earth’s center, considering its semi-major axis. It ensures that the provided parameters are within physically meaningful ranges.

Parameters:

  • r_bn_n_mag (float) – The distance from the Earth’s center to the spacecraft - m.

  • semi_major_axis (float) – The semi-major axis of the spacecraft’s orbit. It must be a non-negative value - m

  • gm (float) – The gravitational parameter, defaulting to Earth’s gravitational parameter if not provided - m^3/s^2.

Returns:

The magnitude of the spacecraft’s orbital velocity - m/s.

Return type:

float

Raises:

  • TypeError – If r or semi_major_axis is not a numeric type.

  • ValueError – If r is less than zero, or semi_major_axis is negative, or the radicand in the calculation is negative.

Example:
>>> calculate_orbital_velocity(7000, 10000)
7.546049108166282
nominalpy.maths.astro.classical_to_non_singular_elements(semi_major_axis: float, eccentricity: float, inclination: float, right_ascension: float, argument_of_periapsis: float, true_anomaly: float) → Tuple[float, float, float, float, float, float]

convert classical orbital elements to non-singular orbital elements as defined in the PhD Thesis: D’Amico, S. (2010). Autonomous Formation Flying in Low Earth Orbit [Delft University of Technology]. http://www.narcis.nl/publication/RecordID/oai:tudelft.nl:uuid:a10e2d63-399d-48e5-884b-402e9a105c70, Page 21

This set of non-singular orbital elements are often used to parameterize the relative motion between two spacecraft

Parameters:

  • semi_major_axis (float) – Semi-major axis of the orbit in meters

  • eccentricity (float) – Eccentricity of the orbit

  • inclination (float) – Inclination of the orbit in radians

  • right_ascension (float) – Right ascension of the ascending node in radians

  • argument_of_periapsis (float) – Argument of periapsis in radians

  • true_anomaly (float) – True anomaly at the epoch in radians

Returns:

A tuple containing the non-singular orbital elements (

semi_major_axis, e_x: x component of eccentricity, e_y: y component of eccentricity inclination, right_ascension, mean argument of latitude

)

Return type:

tuple

)

Return type:

nominalpy.maths.astro.classical_to_vector_elements(semi_major_axis: float, eccentricity: float = 0.0, inclination: float = 0.0, right_ascension: float = 0.0, argument_of_periapsis: float = 0.0, true_anomaly: float = 0.0, planet: str = 'earth') → tuple

Transforms Keplerian orbital elements into position and velocity in Planet-Centered Inertial (PCI) coordinates.

Given the Keplerian orbital elements, this function calculates the orbital state (position and velocity) in the PCI coordinate system. This transformation is essential in astrodynamics for orbit propagation and analysis. The function first computes the gravitational parameter of the planet, then calculates the semi-latus rectum, and finally computes the position and velocity in perifocal coordinates. These are then transformed into PCI coordinates.

Parameters:

  • semi_major_axis (float) – Semi-major axis of the orbit in meters

  • eccentricity (float) – Eccentricity of the orbit (default 0.0)

  • inclination (float) – Inclination of the orbit in radians (default 0.0)

  • right_ascension (float) – Right ascension of the ascending node in radians (default 0.0)

  • argument_of_periapsis (float) – Argument of periapsis in radians (default 0.0)

  • true_anomaly (float) – True anomaly at the epoch in radians (default 0.0)

  • planet (str) – Name of the central body being orbited (default “earth”)

Returns:

Return type:

nominalpy.maths.astro.classical_to_vector_elements_deg(semi_major_axis: float, eccentricity: float = 0.0, inclination: float = 0.0, right_ascension: float = 0.0, argument_of_periapsis: float = 0.0, true_anomaly: float = 0.0, planet: str = 'earth') → tuple

Transforms Keplerian orbital elements into position and velocity in Planet-Centered Inertial (PCI) coordinates.

Given the Keplerian orbital elements, this function calculates the orbital state (position and velocity) in the PCI coordinate system. This transformation is essential in astrodynamics for orbit propagation and analysis. The function first computes the gravitational parameter of the planet, then calculates the semi-latus rectum, and finally computes the position and velocity in perifocal coordinates. These are then transformed into PCI coordinates.

Parameters:

  • semi_major_axis (float) – Semi-major axis of the orbit in meters

  • eccentricity (float) – Eccentricity of the orbit (default 0.0)

  • inclination (float) – Inclination of the orbit in degrees (default 0.0)

  • right_ascension (float) – Right ascension of the ascending node in degrees (default 0.0)

  • argument_of_periapsis (float) – Argument of periapsis in degrees (default 0.0)

  • true_anomaly (float) – True anomaly at the epoch in degrees (default 0.0)

  • planet (str) – Name of the central body being orbited (default “earth”)

Returns:

A tuple containing position and velocity vectors in PCI coordinates

Return type:

tuple

nominalpy.maths.astro.future_relative_state_cw(omega: float, initial_state: ndarray, accelerations: ndarray, t: float) → ndarray

Calculate the future relative positions and velocities (x, y, z, dot_x, dot_y, dot_z) using the state transition matrix based on the analytical solutions to the Clohessy-Wiltshire equations, considering an input of initial relative position and velocity.

Parameters:

  • omega (float) – The orbital angular velocity of the reference orbit (rad/s).

  • initial_state (numpy.ndarray) – The initial state vector containing the relative position and velocity [x0, y0, z0, dot_x0, dot_y0, dot_z0].

  • accelerations (numpy.ndarray) – The vector of constant accelerations in the x, y, and z directions [ax, ay, az].

  • t (float) – The time at which the future state is sought (seconds).

Returns:

The future state vector containing relative positions and velocities [x, y, z, dot_x, dot_y, dot_z] at time t.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

This function computes the future state by applying the state transition matrix to the initial state and incorporating the effect of constant accelerations. The analytical expressions for the state transition matrix and the effect of constant accelerations are derived from the Clohessy-Wiltshire equations.

Example usage: >>> omega = 0.001 # Example orbital angular velocity in rad/s >>> initial_state = np.array([10, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0]) # Example initial state >>> accelerations = np.array([0, 0, 0]) # Example: No acceleration >>> t = 600 # Future state after 10 minutes >>> future_state = calculate_future_state_with_matrix(omega, initial_state, accelerations, t) >>> print(future_state)

nominalpy.maths.astro.geodetic_lla_to_pcpf(lla: ndarray, planet='Earth') → ndarray

Returns:

nominalpy.maths.astro.get_sun_synchronous_inclination_estimate(orbit_mean_motion: float, semi_latus_rectum: float, planet_radius: float, planet_semi_major_axis: float, planet_j2: float, planet: str)

Calculates the sun synchronous inclination estimate based on the position of the planet relative to the sun and the mean and perturbed motion of the orbit.

  • perturbed_motion (float) – [s^-2] The perturbed motion of the orbit

  • planet_semi_major_axis (float) – [m] The sun-body radius of the orbit of the orbiting body

  • planet_j2 (float) – [-] The orbiting body J2 value

  • planet (str) – [m^3 s^-2] The gravitational Mu parameter of the parent of the orbital body

Returns:

[rad] The estimated inclination of the orbit

Return type:

float

nominalpy.maths.astro.mean_to_osculating_elements(req: float, j2: float, semi_major_axis: float, eccentricity: float, inclination: float, right_ascension: float, argument_of_periapsis: float, true_anomaly: float, mean_to_osculating: bool) → Tuple[float, float, float, float, float, float]

First-order J2 Mapping Between Mean and Osculating Orbital Elements Analytical Mechanics of Space Systems, Hanspeter Schaub, John L. Junkins, 4th edition. [m] or [km] should be the same both for req and elements.

Parameters:

  • req (float) – [m] Equatorial radius or the orbital body

  • j2 (float) – [-] J2 parameter for the orbital body of interest

  • semi_major_axis (float) – [m] Semi-major axis of the orbit

  • eccentricity (float) – [-] Eccentricity of the orbit

  • inclination (float) – [rad] Inclination of the orbit

  • right_ascension (float) – [rad] Right ascension of the ascending node of the orbit

  • argument_of_periapsis (float) – [rad] Argument of periapsis of the orbit

  • true_anomaly (float) – [rad] True anomaly of the orbit

  • mean_to_osculating (bool) – [-] Sgn=True:mean to osc, Sgn=False:osc to mean

Returns:

[-] A classical element struct (

semi_major_axis, eccentricity, inclination, raan, argument_of_periapsis, true_anomaly

)

Return type:

tuple

nominalpy.maths.astro.perifocal_to_vector_elements(r_bp_p: ndarray, v_bp_p: ndarray, right_ascension: float = 0, inclination: float = 0, argument_of_periapsis: float = 0) → tuple

Converts position and velocity vectors from perifocal to Planet-Centered Inertial (PCI) coordinates.

Given position and velocity vectors in the perifocal coordinate system (PQW), along with orbital elements such as right ascension of the ascending node, inclination, and argument of perigee, this function transforms these vectors into the ECI coordinate system. The transformation is performed using a matrix obtained from the t_perifocal_to_vector function, which constructs the transformation matrix based on the provided orbital elements.

Parameters:

  • r_bp_p (numpy.ndarray) – Position vector in perifocal coordinates.

  • v_bp_p (numpy.ndarray) – Velocity vector in perifocal coordinates.

  • right_ascension (float) – Right ascension of the ascending node in radians. Defaults to 0.

  • inclination (float) – Orbital inclination in radians. Defaults to 0.

  • argument_of_periapsis (float) – Argument of periapsis in radians. Defaults to 0.

Returns:

Tuple of transformed position and velocity vectors in ECI coordinates.

Return type:

(numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray)

nominalpy.maths.astro.semi_lactus_rectum(semi_major_axis: float, eccentricity: float) → float

nominalpy.maths.astro.semi_latus_rectum_to_vector_elements(semi_latus_rectum: float, eccentricity: float = 0.0, inclination: float = 0.0, right_ascension: float = 0.0, argument_of_periapsis: float = 0.0, true_anomaly: float = 0.0, planet: str = 'earth') → tuple

Transforms Keplerian orbital elements into position and velocity in Planet-Centered Inertial (PCI) coordinates. by taking semi-latus rectum as direct input, this function is valid for all orbits including parabolic and hyperbolic.

Given the Keplerian orbital elements, this function calculates the orbital state (position and velocity) in the PCI coordinate system. This transformation is essential in astrodynamics for orbit propagation and analysis. The function first computes the gravitational parameter of the planet, then calculates the semi-latus rectum, and finally computes the position and velocity in perifocal coordinates. These are then transformed into PCI coordinates.

Parameters:

  • semi_latus_rectum (float) – Semi-latus rectum of the orbit in meters

  • eccentricity (float) – Eccentricity of the orbit (default 0.0)

  • inclination (float) – Inclination of the orbit in radians (default 0.0)

  • right_ascension (f loat) – Right ascension of the ascending node in radians (default 0.0)

  • argument_of_periapsis (float) – Argument of periapsis in radians (default 0.0)

  • true_anomaly (float) – True anomaly at the epoch in radians (default 0.0)

  • planet (str) – Name of the central body being orbited (default “earth”)

Returns:

A tuple containing position and velocity vectors in PCI coordinates

Return type:

tuple

nominalpy.maths.astro.sun_synchronous_inclination(planet: str, semi_major_axis: float, eccentricity: float = 0.0) → float

Returns the inclination in radians of a defined SSO orbit based on the semi major axis and desired eccentricity of the orbit.

Parameters:

  • planet (str) – [-] The orbiting planet to orbit around

  • semi_major_axis (float) – [m] The SMA of the orbit

  • eccentricity (float) – [-] The eccentricity of the orbit

Returns:

[rad] The inclination angle of the orbit

float

nominalpy.maths.astro.t_dot_lvlh_eci(r_bn_n_chief: ndarray, v_bn_n_chief: ndarray, a_bn_n_chief: ndarray = None) → ndarray
Calculate the time derivative of the transformation matrix of the LVLH frame based on the chief spacecraft’s state

vector.

Parameters:

r_bn_n_chief – Position vector of the chief spacecraft in the ECI frame relative to the ECI frame

:type np.ndarray :param v_bn_n_chief: Velocity vector of the chief spacecraft in the ECI frame relative to the ECI frame :type np.ndarray :param a_bn_n_chief: Acceleration vector of the chief spacecraft in the ECI frame relative to the ECI frame :type np.ndarray

:returns the time derivative of the transformation matrix from ECI to LVLH centred on the chief spacecraft [

i_r_dot: Time derivative of the unit radial vector, numpy array (3,) i_theta_dot: Time derivative of the unit transverse vector, numpy array (3,) i_h_dot: Time derivative of the unit normal vector, numpy array (3,)

] :rtype np.ndarray

nominalpy.maths.astro.t_lvlh_eci(r_bn_n_chief: ndarray, v_bn_n_chief: ndarray) → ndarray

Calculate the transformation matrix of the LVLH frame based on the chief spacecraft’s state vector.

Parameters:

r_bn_n_chief – Position vector of the chief spacecraft in the ECI frame relative to the ECI frame

:type np.ndarray :param v_bn_n_chief: Velocity vector of the chief spacecraft in the ECI frame relative to the ECI frame :type np.ndarray

:returns the transformation matrix from ECI to LVLH centred on the chief spacecraft [

i_r: Unit radial vector, numpy array (3,) i_theta: Unit transverse vector, numpy array (3,) i_h: Unit normal vector, numpy array (3,)

] :rtype np.ndarray

nominalpy.maths.astro.t_perifocal_to_vector_elements(right_ascension: float = 0, argument_of_periapsis: float = 0, inclination: float = 0) → ndarray

Creates the transformation matrix to convert perifocal coordinates into Planet-Centered Inertial (PCI) coordinates.

This function computes the transformation matrix using the right ascension of the ascending node, the argument of periapsis, and the orbital inclination. These parameters are expected to be in radians. The transformation matrix is computed based on classical orbital elements, and it’s used in orbital mechanics to convert coordinates from the perifocal (or orbital plane) coordinate system, where the x-axis points towards the periapsis, to the PCI coordinate system.

Parameters:

  • right_ascension (float) – The right ascension of the ascending node in radians

  • argument_of_periapsis (float) – The argument of periapsis in radians

  • inclination (float) – The orbital inclination in radians

Returns:

A 3x3 numpy matrix representing the transformation from perifocal to ECI coordinates.

Return type:

numpy.matrix

nominalpy.maths.astro.true_to_eccentric_anomaly(true_anomaly: float, eccentricity: float) → float

Maps true anomaly angles into eccentric anomaly angles. :param true_anomaly: [rad] True anomaly angle :type true_anomaly: float :param eccentricity: [-] Eccentricity (0 <= e < 1) :type eccentricity: float :return: [rad] Eccentric anomaly :rtype: float

nominalpy.maths.astro.true_to_mean_anomaly(true_anomaly: float, eccentricity: float) → float

Calculate the mean anomaly from the true anomaly.

Parameters:

  • true_anomaly (float) – [rad] The true anomaly of the orbit

  • eccentricity (float) – [-] The eccentricity of the orbit (0 <= e < 1)

Returns:

[rad] Mean elliptic anomaly

Return type:

float

nominalpy.maths.astro.vector_to_classical_elements(r_bn_n: ndarray, v_bn_n: ndarray, planet: str = 'earth') → tuple

Convert state vectors to classical orbital elements. This function calculates the classical orbital elements from the given position and velocity vectors. It supports different planetary bodies by adjusting the gravitational parameter. The function calculates various orbital elements including angular momentum, node vector, eccentricity vector, semi-major axis, inclination, RAAN, argument of periapsis, and true anomaly. It handles different types of orbits: circular equatorial, equatorial elliptical, circular inclined, and classical elliptical inclined.

Parameters:

  • r_bn_n (np.ndarray) – The position vector in a Cartesian coordinate system in metres.

  • v_bn_n (np.ndarray) – The velocity vector in the same Cartesian coordinate system as r_bn_n in metres per second.

  • planet (str) – The name of the planet for which the gravitational parameter is needed. Defaults to ‘earth’.

Returns:

A tuple of classical orbital elements: semi-major axis, eccentricity, inclination, right ascension of the ascending node (RAAN), argument of periapsis, and true anomaly.

Return type:

tuple

Raises:

ArithmeticError – If the orbit is parabolic, which is not supported by this function.

nominalpy.maths.astro.vector_to_classical_elements_mean(r_bn_n: ndarray, v_bn_n: ndarray, planet: str = 'earth') → Tuple[float, float, float, float, float, float]

Converts the position and velocity vectors into mean classical orbital elements.

Parameters:

  • r_bn_n (np.ndarray) – The position vector in the inertial frame [m]

  • v_bn_n (np.ndarray) – The velocity vector in the inertial frame [m/s]

  • planet (str) – The planet to use for the conversion

Returns:

A tuple containing the classical orbital elements (

mean semi_major_axis, mean eccentricity, mean inclination, mean right_ascension, mean argument_of_periapsis, mean true_anomaly

)

Return type:

tuple

nominalpy.maths.astro.vector_to_relative_elements(r_bn_n_leader: ndarray, v_bn_n_leader: ndarray, r_bn_n_follower: ndarray, v_bn_n_follower: ndarray, planet: str = 'earth') → Tuple[float, float, float, float, float, float]

Convert the relative position and velocity vectors to relative orbital elements as defined in the PhD Thesis: D’Amico, S. (2010). Autonomous Formation Flying in Low Earth Orbit [Delft University of Technology]. http://www.narcis.nl/publication/RecordID/oai:tudelft.nl:uuid:a10e2d63-399d-48e5-884b-402e9a105c70, Page 21

Parameters:

  • r_bn_n_leader (np.ndarray) – Position vector of the leader in the inertial frame in meters

  • v_bn_n_leader (np.ndarray) – Velocity vector of the leader in the inertial frame in meters per second

  • r_bn_n_follower (np.ndarray) – Position vector of the follower in the inertial frame in meters

  • v_bn_n_follower (np.ndarray) – Velocity vector of the follower in the inertial frame in meters per second

  • planet (str) – The name of the planet used to search for the Gravitational parameter of the central body in meters cubed per second squared

Returns:

A tuple containing the relative orbital elements (

da: the relative semi-major axis [m] dex: relative e_x [m] dix: relative x component of inclination [m] diy: relative y component of inclination [m] dey: relative e_y [m] daoml: change in mean argument of latitude [m]

)

Return type:

tuple

nominalpy.maths.astro.vector_to_relative_elements_mean(r_bn_n_leader: ndarray, v_bn_n_leader: ndarray, r_bn_n_follower: ndarray, v_bn_n_follower: ndarray, planet: str = 'earth') → Tuple[float, float, float, float, float, float]

Convert the relative position and velocity vectors to relative orbital elements as defined in the PhD Thesis: D’Amico, S. (2010). Autonomous Formation Flying in Low Earth Orbit [Delft University of Technology]. http://www.narcis.nl/publication/RecordID/oai:tudelft.nl:uuid:a10e2d63-399d-48e5-884b-402e9a105c70, Page 21

Parameters:

  • r_bn_n_leader (np.ndarray) – Position vector of the leader in the inertial frame in meters

  • v_bn_n_leader (np.ndarray) – Velocity vector of the leader in the inertial frame in meters per second

  • r_bn_n_follower (np.ndarray) – Position vector of the follower in the inertial frame in meters

  • v_bn_n_follower (np.ndarray) – Velocity vector of the follower in the inertial frame in meters per second

  • planet (str) – The name of the planet used to search for the Gravitational parameter of the central body in meters cubed per second squared

Returns:

A tuple containing the relative orbital elements (

da: the relative mean semi-major axis [m] dex: relative mean e_x [m] dix: relative mean x component of inclination [m] diy: relative mean y component of inclination [m] dey: relative mean e_y [m] daoml: change in mean, mean argument of latitude [m]

)

Return type:

tuple

nominalpy.maths.computer_library module

nominalpy.maths.computer_library.create_command(command: str, parameters: dict, time: float = 0.0) → dict

Creates a command with a list of arguments as the parameters. This will create the JSON object with the list of parameters required.

Parameters:

  • command (str) – The command to execute.

  • parameters (dict) – The parameter dictionary containing keys and values for the command.

  • time (float, optional) – The time [s] that the command must be executed at, default is 0.0.

Returns:

The JSON command that can be used.

Return type:

dict

nominalpy.maths.computer_library.create_guidance_command(navigation: str = 'Simple', pointing: str = 'Inertial', controller: str = 'MRP', mapping: str = 'ReactionWheels', time: float = 0.0) → dict

Creates a guidance command for the spacecraft operation computer to execute once loaded into the system at a particular time.

Parameters:

  • navigation (str, optional) – The navigation mode to set (default is “Simple”).

  • pointing (str, optional) – The pointing mode to set (default is “Inertial”).

  • controller (str, optional) – The controller mode to set (default is “MRP”).

  • mapping (str, optional) – The mapping mode to set (default is “ReactionWheels”).

  • time (float, optional) – The time [s] at which the command is executed, default is 0.0.

Returns:

The appropriate command JSON to be executed.

Return type:

dict

  • mapping (str) – The mapping mode to set.

abstract init_classical_elements(*args, **kwargs)
initialize the orbital elements for every spacecraft in the constellation, if the orbital element

properties of this class are osculating then the initial orbital elements will be osculating, otherwise they will be mean

set_mean_elements(semi_major_axis_mean: float = None, eccentricity_mean: float = None, inclination_mean: float = None, right_ascension_mean: float = None, argument_of_periapsis_mean: float = None, true_anomaly_mean: float = None, **kwargs)

set the mean orbital elements for every spacecraft in the constellation

Parameters:

  • semi_major_axis_mean (float) – the mean semi-major axis of every spacecraft in the constellation

  • eccentricity_mean (float) – the mean eccentricity of every spacecraft in the constellation

  • inclination_mean (float) – the mean inclination of every spacecraft in the constellation

  • right_ascension_mean (float) – the mean offset in right ascension

  • argument_of_periapsis_mean (float) – the mean offset in argument of periapsis

  • true_anomaly_mean (float) – the mean offset in true anomaly

Returns:

set_variable(spacecraft_ids: int | List[int] | None = None, **kwargs)
set variables for spacecraft in the constellation where the variables are input into the method as keyword

arguments

Parameters:

  • spacecraft_ids (Optional[Union[int, List[int]]]) – the spacecraft ids to set the variable for. If None, then the variable will be set for every spacecraft in the constellation

  • kwargs – the variables to set for the spacecraft in the constellation

nominalpy.maths.data module

This module contains public methods that can calculate various data-related functions for the TT&C system. These include bits and byte conversions.

nominalpy.maths.data.bytes_to_bits(bytes: float) → int

Convert a quantity from bytes to bits. This function calculates the number of bits that correspond to a given number of bytes. Note that 1 byte equals 8 bits.

Parameters:

bytes (float) – The number of bytes to be converted.

Returns:

The equivalent number of bits.

Return type:

int

nominalpy.maths.data.gigabytes_to_bits(gigabytes: float) → int

Parameters:

gigabytes (float) – The number of gigabytes to be converted.

Returns:

The equivalent number of bits.

Return type:

int

nominalpy.maths.data.gigabytes_to_bytes(gigabytes: float) → int

Parameters:

gigabytes (float) – The number of gigabytes to be converted.

Returns:

The equivalent number of bits.

Return type:

int

Parameters:

  • forward – A unit vector representing the forward axis.

  • up – A unit vector representing the up axis.

nominalpy.maths.mass.inertia_inverse_point_transform(inertia: ndarray, dcm: ndarray, position: ndarray, mass: float) → ndarray

Transform an inertia tensor from a new frame back to the center-of-mass frame.

Parameters:

  • inertia (numpy.ndarray) – The inertia tensor in the new frame [3x3 matrix]

  • dcm (numpy.ndarray) – The DCM of the transformation [-]

  • position (numpy.ndarray) – The position of the new frame relative to the original frame [m]

  • mass (float) – The mass of the object [kg]

Returns:

The transformed inertia tensor in the original frame [3x3 matrix]

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

nominalpy.maths.mass.moment_of_inertia_prime_L_to_B(moiPrime_L_L: ndarray, dcm_LB: ndarray, com_B_B: ndarray, comDot_B_B: ndarray, mass: float) → ndarray

Converts a Moment of Inertia Prime (which is a derivative) from the L frame to a B frame.

Parameters:

  • moiPrime_L_L (numpy.ndarray) – The moment of inertia in the L frame [kg m^2/s]

  • dcm_LB (numpy.ndarray) – The rotation matrix from the L to B frame [-]

  • com_B_B (numpy.ndarray) – The center of mass in the B frame [m]

  • comDot_B_B (numpy.ndarray) – The center of mass change in time in the B frame [m/s]

  • mass (float) – The mass of the object [kg]

Returns:

The moment of inertia in the B frame [kg m^2/s]

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

nominalpy.maths.utils module

This module contains public methods that aid with mathematical calculations and astrophysical dimensions.

nominalpy.maths.utils.acos_quadrant_check(adjacent: float, hypotenuse: float, test: float) → float

Calculate an angle using the arccosine function and perform a quadrant check. The function calculates the angle using the arccosine of the ratio of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse. It adjusts the angle based on the quadrant determined by the ‘test’ parameter.

Parameters:

  • adjacent (float) – The length of the adjacent side of a right triangle.

  • hypotenuse (float) – The length of the hypotenuse of the triangle.

  • test (float) – A value to determine the quadrant of the angle.

Returns:

The calculated angle in radians.

Return type:

float

nominalpy.maths.utils.angle_between_vectors(v1: ndarray, v2: ndarray) → float

Calculate the angle between two vectors. This function calculates the angle between two vectors using the dot product and the magnitude of each vector. The angle is calculated using the arccosine function.

Parameters:

  • v1 (np.ndarray) – The first vector

  • v2 (np.ndarray) – The second vector

Returns:

The angle between the two vectors in radians.

Return type:

float

normalize an angle between 0 <= theta < max, where max is an arbitrary angle

Parameters:

  • angle (float) – The angle to be normalized

  • angle_max (float) – The maximum value for the angle

Returns:

The normalized angle

float

nominalpy.maths.utils.normalize_array(array: ndarray) → ndarray

nominalpy.maths.utils.perpendicular_vector(v1: ndarray, v_ref: ndarray) → ndarray

Calculate the perpendicular vector of two vectors. This function calculates the perpendicular vector of two vectors using the dot product and the magnitude of each vector. The perpendicular vector is calculated using the dot product and the magnitude of the first vector.

Parameters:

  • v1 (np.ndarray) – The first vector

  • v_ref (np.ndarray) – The second vector

Returns:

The perpendicular vector of the two vectors

Return type:

np.ndarray

nominalpy.maths.utils.shortest_angular_difference(angle1: float, angle2: float) → float

Calculate the shortest angular difference between two angles. This function calculates the shortest angular difference between two angles using the arccosine function and the quadrant check function.

Parameters:

  • angle1 (float) – The first angle

  • angle2 (float) – The second angle

Returns:

The shortest angular difference between the two angles

Return type:

float

nominalpy.maths.utils.unit_vector_derivative(u: ndarray, udot: ndarray) → ndarray

Calculate the time derivative of a unit vector.

Parameters:

  • u (numpy.ndarray) – The original vector.

  • udot (numpy.ndarray) – The time derivative of the original vector.

Returns:

The time derivative of the unit vector derived from the original vector.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

Computes the time derivative of a unit vector given a vector and its time derivative. If the magnitude of the original vector is zero, returns a zero vector to avoid division by zero.

Example:

>>> u = np.array([1, 0, 0])
>>> udot = np.array([0, 1, 0])
>>> unit_vector_derivative(u, udot)
array([0., 1., 0.])
